connections.label: Joseph Rayner / Maxwell Rayner
connections.description: Joseph Rayner is the soldier whose remains were found near Wilfred Owen in MAG-007. Maxwell Rayner is the defrocked minister who led the Peoples' Church of the Divine Host, mentioned in MAG-009. Jonathan Sims notes the name familiarity, suggesting a possible link.
connections.evidence: In MAG-007, Joseph Rayner is the dead soldier found near Owen. In MAG-009, Maxwell Rayner is the cult leader whose pendant symbol appears on victims. Jonathan Sims explicitly notes recognizing the name Rayner.

connections.label: Gertrude Robinson
connections.description: Gertrude Robinson is mentioned as the previous Head Archivist who died under unclear circumstances. She is first referenced in MAG-001, and her mysterious death is pondered in MAG-011.
connections.evidence: In MAG-011, Jonathan Sims reflects on Gertrude's death and her absence. In MAG-001, she is mentioned as the former archivist whose chaotic filing system he inherited.

connections.label: Graham Folger
connections.description: Antonio Blake mentions his ex-boyfriend Graham. which may be the same Graham who was replaced by 'Not-Graham' in MAG-003.
connections.evidence: Blake refers to his ex-boyfriend Graham.

connections.label: Gerard Keay
connections.description: Gerard Keay appears in MAG-012 as a burned patient who kills a cultist. He is the son of Mary Keay, owner of Pinhole Books in MAG-004, and was acquitted of her murder.
connections.evidence: In MAG-012, Gerard Keay is identified as the burned man with eye tattoos. In MAG-004, he is mentioned as Mary Keay's son who was acquitted of her murder.

connections.label: Elthorne Road, Archway
connections.description: Elthorne Road is referenced in MAG-016 as a nearby residential street, and is the location of the attack described in MAG-006.
connections.evidence: MAG-016: 'While nearby Elthorne Road was full of houses and gardens...' MAG-006: 'Elthorne Road, Archway, London, England' is a documented location.
connections.location_relation: Same London district, street mentioned in both.

connections.label: Jurgen Leitner / Leitner Books
connections.description: The book 'The Boneturner's Tale' is explicitly identified as another volume from the library of Jurgen Leitner, first mentioned in MAG-004 ('Ex Altiora'). Jonathan Sims confirms the connection and expresses concern.
connections.evidence: MAG-017: Sebastian finds a library label underneath for 'Jergensburg or Jurgenleit'. Sims states: 'I've already uncovered evidence of two separate surviving books from Jurgen Leitner's library.' MAG-004 first introduced Leitner and his dangerous books.

connections.label: Michael Crew
connections.description: Michael Crew is identified as the person who returned 'The Boneturner's Tale' to Chiswick Library. He was previously mentioned in MAG-004 as the childhood friend of statement giver Dominic Swain, who was struck by lightning and bears Lichtenberg scars.
connections.evidence: MAG-017: 'His name, at least according to his library card, was Michael Crew'. MAG-004: Dominic Swain states 'His name was Michael Crew' and describes him as his childhood friend struck by lightning.

connections.label: Clapham, London
connections.description: Christof Rudenko mentions moving to a house in Clapham with friends after the events at Welbeck House. Clapham is also the location of Amy Patel's flat in MAG-003, where she witnessed the creature and 'Not-Graham'.
connections.evidence: MAG-018: 'I did move out in the end, and now live in a house in Clapham with some friends.' MAG-003: Location is 'Clapham, London, England'.
connections.location_relation: Same London district mentioned in both statements.

connections.label: 105 Hill Top Road
connections.description: Father Burroughs visits Hill Top Road, the same house from Ivo Lensik's statement in MAG-008. Both experience supernatural phenomena at this location.
connections.evidence: MAG-019: Burroughs is called to 'a house up on Hill Top Road' where he experiences intense heat. MAG-008: Ivo Lensik's statement about supernatural events at 105 Hill Top Road.

connections.label: Ivo Lensik
connections.description: The 'builder' or 'gentleman' treated at John Radcliffe Hospital and mentioned in Burroughs' statement is Ivo Lensik, the statement giver from MAG-008.
connections.evidence: MAG-019: 'a gentleman had been admitted to the John Radcliffe after having something of a scare in a house up on Hill Top Road.' MAG-008: Ivo Lensik gives statement about Hill Top Road experiences.

connections.label: Anne 'Annie' Kasuma-Willett
connections.description: Anne Kasuma-Willett is named in MAG-008 as a witness to Agnes Montague's death and appears in MAG-019 as the nurse who contacts Father Burroughs.
connections.evidence: MAG-019: Annie is the nurse who calls Burroughs. MAG-008 Archivist Note: 'Agnes Montague died in Sheffield in 2006 with a severed hand chained to her waist. Anne Kasuma-Willett witnessed this.'

connections.label: Breekon & Hope Deliveries
connections.description: Breekon & Hope delivered a pale yellow stole to The Oratory in Oxford, which vanished shortly after. This is the same delivery service that delivered the mysterious coffin in MAG-002.
connections.evidence: MAG-020 Archivist Note: 'the package was handed to them by a company called Breekon and Hope Deliveries.' MAG-002 Supplemental: 'Breekon and Hope delivery service existed but records are unavailable.'

connections.label: 89 Bullingdon Road
connections.description: The location of Father Burroughs' crimes (the murder of two students) as revealed in the MAG-020 investigation, is the same house from MAG-019 where he first encountered the 'Mentis' writing.
connections.evidence: MAG-020 Archivist Note: 'Father Burroughs was found in one of the back rooms of 89 Bullingdon Road.' This is the same address investigated in MAG-019.

connections.label: Boothby Road Investigation
connections.description: Martin Blackwood's statement is a direct follow-up to his investigation of Carlos Vittery's flat at Boothby Road, the primary location from MAG-016.
connections.evidence: MAG-022 begins with Martin describing his investigation of 'that flat that he lived in down in Boothby Road', referring to Carlos Vittery from MAG-016.

connections.label: Jane Prentiss
connections.description: Martin identifies the worm-infested entity in the basement as Jane Prentiss, the same 'witch' or parasite-host from Timothy Hodge's statement (MAG-006).
connections.evidence: Martin states: 'I realized that this woman must be that Jane Prentiss you were telling us about.' He also references the 'case where that woman... burst into worms' from MAG-006.

connections.label: Von Closen -> Keay Family Lineage
connections.description: Archivist research reveals Wilhelm von Closen (Albrecht's nephew) is a direct ancestor of Mary Keay (owner of Pinhole Books from MAG-004). This connects the historical German statement to the modern Leitner book plotline.
connections.evidence: MAG-023 Supplemental: '...one branch emigrated to England in 1908. They had a daughter, Elsa, who went on to marry a man by the name of Michael Keay in 1920. In 1924, they had one daughter, whose name was Mary Keay.'
